title: Palmar and Dorsal Fascia Compartments
summary: Slice the hand into compartments (thenar, hypothenar, midpalmar, adductor, dorsal) and connect each to infection spread pathways and surgical releases.
high_yield: Midpalmar vs. thenar space separation is key for deep infections—show the septa boundaries.
Parona’s space continuity with forearm flexor compartment explains horseshoe abscess routes.
Emphasize dorsal subaponeurotic space for bite wound spread.
pitfalls: Learners confuse lumbrical canals with fascial spaces—call them out separately.
Avoid suggesting spaces are always present cavities—note they are potential spaces opened by pathology.

animation_timeline.narration: Begin with palmar fascia cross-section, coloring thenar, hypothenar, midpalmar, and adductor compartments.
animation_timeline.visual: Transverse slice diagram with color-coded compartments and labels.

animation_timeline.narration: Show longitudinal view tracing the midpalmar space proximally to Parona’s space; animate infection arrow.
animation_timeline.visual: Side view with red arrow following flexor tendons into forearm.

animation_timeline.narration: Flip to dorsal hand highlighting subcutaneous vs. subaponeurotic layers and lymphatic drainage to epitrochlear/axillary nodes.
animation_timeline.visual: Dorsal overlay with lymphatic arrows and caution icon for human bites.
